instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V4_G3H: What is PP3V4_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V3_G3H When you see PP3V4_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V3_G3H.
definitions.3V3S5_EN: What is 3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
got in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> appears to have been cleaned.  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> giving me 7.65-8.5v with charger plugged in. it bounces around slowly from 8-7 or 6v and then back up to 8 something.  battery only is 1.5-2 volts.  and it wont stay a steady voltage. checked the res on pin 27-28 and 17-18 on isl swapped the isl with a good one same thing. will not power from battery either.  i have <SIGNAL>PP3V4_G3H</SIGNAL>.  <RESISTOR>R5403</RESISTOR> does not look good its giving 0 to .03 volts not that it should be putting out voltage necessary. im finding some corrostion and obvious liquid around the l6707 up the board <DIODE>D4610</DIODE> right next to the smc. i did a smc by pass and nothing happened. 

not sure if these symptoms have any obvious part / place to look or if need to just check every rail.  

Thanks 
Nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
L7260 is flashing 0 volts to 3.3v back to 0 and just cycling this. reminds me of a blinking light. on and off consistently.   

<SIGNAL>3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>  going from .34 to 1.2 to 3.4 and cycling through them over and over.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: Checked for shorts on 5V and 3V rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v cycling to 0 and back up
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0.25v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.03v to 0.35v back and forth
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 4.28-2.98 jumping all around in between 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_ISNS_R</SIGNAL> = 0v

voltage drop to ground diode mode.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.093v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.40
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.28
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.404
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0.39
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v does that mean short to GND there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: i looked into everything <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is connected to and nothing is shorting to ground on that rail.  is something not telling <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> to turn on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: What is resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: 0v to gnd in diode mode or .06k in res mode.  should be .49 or something similar to that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: Well there is your problem. Inject 5V and see if there is any current draw for something to heat up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3402</CHIP> is getting the hottest, <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> is second hottest both up to 97 degrees <CHIP>U3402</CHIP> gets up to 98.9 degrees. the <TRANSISTOR>Q4590</TRANSISTOR> was getting hot also but not as hot.  The rest of the board is in low 80's..

I tried replacing them both and just pulling them off and checking res. nothing changed. also when injecting voltage trying to inject 5v and it was taking in about 1v up to 5 amps.

is this likely a break in the line? or something i missed here?

I have already gone over every part in the <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> line previously i replaced every part starting with the liquid damaged areas. i checked res after every part i pulled and nothing had changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: <CHIP>U3402</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> are both on 3V line. No idea what you are doing....<RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> getting hot would suggest a short on L3404 side. But how they would heat up if injecting on 5V rail is a mystery to me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: i am injecting voltage into the <CAPACITOR>C7510</CAPACITOR>,  i also have no idea why i'm getting hot on 3v components.. i double checked again an def getting up to 100 degrees on the <CHIP>U3402</CHIP> and it goes down it temp when im checking over the <TRANSISTOR>Q4590</TRANSISTOR> witch is on the 5v rail.  i double check res to ground on the 3v rails and everything checks out good. really confused here how i'm reading higher temps on a 3v rail than on the 5v that im injecting into.. perhaps something else is getting hot and my temp gun cannot read correctly.  its weird how i replaced every component and was not able to find the fault to ground. not sure how i can replace every part on the <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> line and have nothing change.  maybe there is something i missed.  it would have to be one of the components on the <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> rails right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: So <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> heating up. Tell me why it would not make sense to replace <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR>. Also tell me why <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> would be heating up and which components could be causing that. Also if you doubt your thermometer use your finger and/or alcohol.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> is a resistor so it should be good unless its fried up, not exactly sure of the correct answer.. i suppose the j3401 connector could be damaged, or <CAPACITOR>C3421</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3422</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3420</CAPACITOR> could be bad, not sure why <RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> would be heating up unless somehow 5v was connected to that rail and that would be bad or somewhere there is a voltage leak in a gate, that is my guess not sure how logical it is but thats what i'm thinking.. 

i tried to feel by finger and dabbing alcohol but is rather hard to find the exact spot with these methods because the components are just not getting hot enough.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: Not hot enough, you said 98C. Anything over 55C will cook your finger.....I don't think I can help any further.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message:
sorry i didn't mean Celsius i meant Fahrenheit. the only question that i have is if i have a short on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and i remove every component on that rail shouldn't i have been able to find the short? unless its a break in the line right? 
thanks for the help Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: I have no idea, probably a short in the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power no charge.
threads.message: okay fair enough for me.  i'm going to toss it to the scrap pile.
